title-group.article-title: Development of design methodology for a synthetic jet actuator array for flow separation control applications

article-meta.aff: 1School of Engineering and Design, Brunel University, UK
2School of Mechanical, Aerospace and Civil Engineering, University of Manchester, UK

author-notes.corresp: Mark Jabbal, School of Engineering and Design, Brunel University, Kingston Lane, Uxbridge UB8 3PH, UK. Email: mark_jabbal@hotmail.com

abstract.p: This article documents the development of synthetic jet actuator array hardware to augment high-lift system effectiveness in a wind tunnel model. The study involved the design, manufacture and bench test of a synthetic jet actuator array based on an inclined actuator configuration to reduce volume installation requirements without a loss in jet velocity relative to a non-inclined baseline model; incorporation of proper synthetic jet actuator systems wiring and internal synthetic jet actuator chamber pressure-sensing for actuator health monitoring. The peak velocity obtained from the inclined synthetic jet actuator array was 100 m/s, which favourably compares to the baseline array (∼90 m/s), while reducing the usable depth requirements by 50%. The final outcome of this study has been to apply the design lessons learned to develop a methodology for designing a synthetic jet actuator array with the constraints of using piezoelectric-based actuator technology for flow separation control applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Active flow control technology is seen as offering potential solutions to challenges in aircraft aerodynamics including drag reduction,1 high-lift system improvement2 and noise reduction.3 Within flow control research, it is thus becoming increasingly important not only to consider the technical issue of ‘does it work’, but rather the technological issue – ‘can it be made to work successfully in practice?’4 To address this, it is important to fully understand the engineering constraints affecting any potential flow control area before deciding a research and implementation strategy.

While this study is concerned with design improvements of a lab-based SJA system, there are wider implications for the lab-to-flight transfer of active flow control systems. Many of the flow control areas envisaged on civil transport aircraft are not only severely volume constrained but also limited by the way in which volume is distributed (‘form factor’); for example, thin is more highly valued than small and spherical. Clearly, there is benefit in reducing volume installation requirements of flow control actuators and added value of embedding actuators in the aircraft skin via removable panels for ease of maintenance and reduced interference with other systems. Table 1 quotes the typical skin thickness values for the high-lift surfaces on the short-range Airbus A320 and long-range Airbus A340 aircrafts where separation control would be envisaged. Table 1.

It is interesting to note from Table 1 that skin thickness does not linearly scale with the size of the aircraft, but is determined by a series of other factors. For example, the A340 outboard flap is much larger than its inboard counterpart and is in the efflux of both engines, hence requiring a thicker skin. Conversely, the inboard flap of the A320 carries the load of the engine, giving it a thicker skin than the outboard flap. The A320 slat is thicker than its A340 counterpart since it has to withstand a bird strike for which there is no other protection of the wing front spar; the A340 fixed D-nose is reinforced with an additional false spar for bird strike protection, hence allowing a thinner slat (Private communication, S Boye, Airbus UK, 2011). What is significant from these observations is that the volume installation constraint for embedding actuators in the aircraft skin does not disappear for larger aircraft.

Development of new manufacturing technologies such as microfabricated electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) has led to the possibility for active flow control to be realised at microscale, with a typical smallest feature size of between 1 mm and 1 micron. MEMS may therefore play a crucial role for separation control on high-lift devices. However, to-date, a low number of satisfactory MEMS fluidic actuators are available. Only a few MEMS pulsed-jet actuator examples showing promising performances have been reported.6–9 In contrast, SJAs based on MEMS technologies10–12 do not present satisfactory performance for flow control applications, essentially because of a deficit of velocity due to a very small variation of the cavity volume. A synthetic jet based on a micro-magneto-mechanical system13 with a full size less than 1 cm3 and a peak jet velocity of 50 m/s represents existing peak performance of a MEMS SJA, which still falls short of the requirements of this study.

At flight level, the inclusion of a health and usage monitoring system (HUMS) is critical for the certification of active flow control actuators as part of a wider aircraft configuration warning system.14 At lab level, HUMS would help to identify gradual and complete actuator failure during wind tunnel testing and therefore improve the robustness of the data acquired. Methods for HUMS in SJA systems may include sensing pressure fluctuations inside the actuator chamber or sensing the electrical current draw of the SJA diaphragm15 (at a given voltage, current draw would be altered due to changes in the chamber pressure). For the latter of these methods, SJA diaphragms incorporating piezoceramic technology are at a particular advantage since the piezoelectric material simultaneously permits sensing via the direct piezoelectric effect (mechanical-to-electrical transduction) and actuation via the reverse piezoelectric effect (electrical-to-mechanical transduction). Self-sensing actuation using piezoceramics has obvious benefits for the potential reduction in electrical wiring and associated hardware and has found favour in structural health monitoring applications.16–18 Furthermore, utilising a part of the piezoceramic actuator as a sensor can also enable the construction of a closed-loop, self-locking operation to the actuator’s resonance frequency regardless of the operational or environmental conditions and ensure optimal operation for energy efficiency.19

The mass cost of distributing power to SJA systems is relatively small compared to the mass costs associated with SJA power generation and management.20 An A320 aircraft case-study shows that the wiring overhead represents less than 10% of the SJA systems’ architecture mass required for separation control application at the trailing-edge flap. However, complexity in wiring interconnectivity increases when the need for redundancy and HUMS are factored in. A simple ‘data bus’ system for HUMS such as Inter-Integrated Circuit (I2 C), which is widely used for instrumentation, offers scope in reducing wiring complexity. Furthermore, self-sensing actuation and the possibility of wirelessly controlling and monitoring flow control devices as part of a wireless aircraft nervous system21,22 offer scope in reducing wiring overhead. That said, power distribution to the actuators has to go down a wire.

sec.title: Design constraints
sec.p: The aim was to design an array of 30 SJAs that could be placed within the leading flap of a three-element wing wind tunnel model. The usable depth in the flap varies between the root, crank and tip sections by approximately 25, 18 (0.3 span) and 9 mm (1 span), respectively. An array designed to a maximum usable depth of 15 mm would allow installation at any location in the flap to an outboard limit of 0.5 span with some excess volume for wiring and bay closure.

A generic SJA consists of a chamber with an oscillating boundary on one or both of its sides and an orifice plate on the other.23,24 The oscillating boundary can take the form of a piston25 or a flexible diaphragm, e.g. electro-active polymer,26 ionic polymer,27 ferromagnetic shape memory alloy28 and piezoelectric.29 Depending on the arrangement of the fixed and oscillating boundaries of the chamber with respect to each other, two SJA configurations can be defined: the ‘opposite’ SJA in which the orifice plate is located opposite or parallel to the oscillating boundary (Figure 1(a)), and the ‘adjacent’ SJA in which the orifice plate is located adjacent or perpendicular to the oscillating boundary (Figure 1(b)). Note that for the adjacent SJA, two oscillating boundaries are feasible. The geometry of a SJA is defined by its orifice diameter d, orifice height h, chamber diameter D and chamber height H. Figure 1.
Opposite and adjacent configurations for SJAs.

The authors have been involved in the development of SJA technology utilising commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) piezoceramic discs for diaphragm implementation.5,30–32 These diaphragms consist of a polycrystalline lead zirconate titanate (PZT) patch bonded to a metallic shim and are readily used due to their availability, low cost and reliability. Previous work31 has shown that the peak jet velocity obtained from a velocity-optimised opposite SJA (h = 2.1 d and H = 0.6 d) with d∼1 mm and D = 25 mm was 130 m/s (referred to as the ‘baseline opposite SJA’ from here on). However, the ratio of actuator spanwise spacing-to-orifice diameter λ in an array of baseline opposite SJAs would be λ∼30, which is outside the range of optimised spacing of 5 ≤ λ ≤ 20 for separation control established from experiments with arrays of vane vortex generators33 and fluidic jets.34,35

Previous SJA arrays developed by the co-authors5,32 have utilised the adjacent SJA configuration in wind tunnel models, for which two logical orientations of the individual actuators are possible: diaphragm diameter parallel or perpendicular to the control surface span line. A parallel orientation was adopted for separation control on the ‘N56’/aileron model.32 Due to model envelope constraints, the array of 17 SJAs was limited to placement in the main element of a three-element model and thus the parallel orientation was chosen to allow the SJA orifices to be positioned closer to the aileron hinge line, albeit at a cost of λ∼30. Results indicated that no discernable flow control effect from the SJAs was recorded.

A perpendicular orientation of the SJA array was utilised for separation control on the European Union FP6 ‘Aerodynamic Validation of Emission Reducing Technologies’ (‘AVERT’)/leading edge droop model.5 The use of the adjacent SJA configuration was required to allow stacking of 40 SJAs with λ∼10. Matching the actuator geometric dimensions to that of the baseline opposite SJA, the peak jet velocity obtained from the AVERT SJA array was ∼90 m/s (referred to as the ‘baseline adjacent SJA’ from here on). Furthermore, a 1.5° delay in the stall angle was recorded. However, the height of the baseline adjacent SJA is ∼30 mm based on the diaphragm diameter (including actuator housing) and therefore exceeds volume installation constraints for the existing flap model envelope.

Figure 2 illustrates the design constraints for SJA implementation in the wind tunnel model, as a function of placement height of the array tA, and λ. In order to meet existing requirements, the value of tA must be reduced by a factor of 0.5 relative to the baseline adjacent SJA in the AVERT design. The aim would be to match the spacing between baseline adjacent SJAs (λ∼10), as this design point demonstrated a SJA flow control effect. Figure 2.
Design constraints for SJA array implementation in the wind tunnel model. SJA: synthetic jet actuator.

One method of reducing tA is to reduce the chamber diameter, which implies a reduction in diaphragm and PZT diameter. The electrical power that can be absorbed by the PZT is proportional to its volume. However, the thickness of the PZT patch is limited by its susceptibility to fracture when deflecting. The use of smaller diameter diaphragms (which are inherently stiffer for a given thickness) therefore implies a reduction in power that can be absorbed and thus a reduction in output fluidic power and peak jet velocity for a given orifice size. It has been shown36 that actuator efficiency and jet exit velocity could be doubled by the use of single-crystal piezoceramic (67%PMN-33%PT) compared to a polycrystalline piezoceramic (PZT-5A) of the same size. However, project time constraints dictated the use of COTS PZT diaphragms rather than a bespoke single-crystal solution. Consequently, the chamber diameter is constrained to D = 25 mm.

Table 2 summarises the design constraints for the present array, including additional constraints identified from experience with the baseline opposite SJA and the baseline adjacent SJA. Table 2.

sec.title: Design strategy
sec.p: An opposite SJA configuration was preferred to the adjacent SJA configuration due to a higher peak jet velocity for the same geometric dimensions, as previously highlighted. It is hypothesised that an additional fluidic loss is incurred in the adjacent SJA chamber as the flow induced by the moving boundary is forced to turn 90° to exit the orifice. The SJA design strategy adopted to overcome the mismatch between optimum actuator spacing (∼10d or 12 mm) and diaphragm diameter (∼25d or 27 mm) for reduced volume installation was based on an inclined opposite SJA configuration.

The 3D computer-aided design (CAD) investigations suggested that it was possible to incline an opposite SJA along the diaphragm plane to an acute angle <20° relative to the wetted surface to allow actuator overlapping, while bringing the orifice spacing to λ∼11, which is close to the required design point (Figure 2). Figure 3 shows the design of the inclined opposite SJA array for which the placement height relative to the baseline adjacent SJA is reduced by a factor of 0.5 (Figure 3(a)) and the geometric constraints of the baseline opposite SJA are met (Table 2). However, inclination of the SJA produces an offset between the centre of the orifice and diaphragm. A modest curvature is incorporated into the orifice duct to keep the offset to a minimum at ∼0.1D. Figure 3.
Arrangement of the inclined opposite SJA array (part view; total 30 SJAs in complete array). SJA: synthetic jet actuator.

The diaphragm is intended to be compressed against the top plate and chamber by a nitrile O-ring for air sealing (and to reduce diaphragm fatigue of the clamped metal shim), which is in turn held in position by an individual cover (Figure 3(b)). The design also incorporates a 6-mm diameter cylindrical microphone housing (Figure 3(c)) connected to each SJA chamber to allow actuator pressure sensing for health monitoring. For clarity, an exploded view of the parts for a single SJA is shown in Figure 3(d).

Figure 4 shows a thin wing section extruded from the inboard profile with the inclined opposite SJA array embedded in the leading flap element. Chordwise stations of the array are included such that the orifice line on the upper surface is located as far fore and aft as feasibly possible (with stations at 10%, 36% and 75% of the element chord, respectively). Excess volume is available between the SJA array and the lower surface of the leading flap at all chordwise stations to permit electrical wiring installation. Figure 4.
Embodiment of SJA arrays in wind tunnel model. (Above): short-span multi-element wing extruded from the inboard profile with SJA array embedded inside the leading flap wing box; arrays stationed at 10%, 36% and 75% of flap chord. (Below): close-up of leading flap element. SJA: synthetic jet actuator.

For the current SJA design, additive manufacturing was used to introduce complex features of the design (e.g. inclined chamber, orifice curvature and microphone housing) that were difficult and costly to include using traditional subtractive machining. The stereolithography (SLA) rapid prototyping technique was used, with the array fabricated out of a SLA polymer (Xtreme®). The geometric freedom conferred by the use of SLA fabrication allowed an arced-wall chamber (with a mean H = 0.6d) for reducing the internal ‘dead air’ region/streamlining flow into the orifice, and filleting of the orifice internal entry to reduce viscous losses during the exhaust cycle. SLA fabrication also reduced the manufacturing lead time relative to conventional metal/electrical discharge machining.

sec.title: Electrical wiring
sec.p: Support electronics for the SJA array include a diaphragm drive system and an actuator health monitoring system. The purpose of the electronic drive system is to provide a capability of driving 30 PZT diaphragms (typically APC International Ltd model: FT-27 T-3.9A1) at the required voltage level simultaneously and in phase. The monitoring system is required to provide integral sensor diagnostics for each SJA chamber, as described further in ‘Health monitoring’ section. Given the number of actuators and equivalent number of microphones for health monitoring, particular emphasis was directed on providing proper wiring and where possible, to streamline the wiring for installation of the array in the wind tunnel model.

The initial aim was to drive the diaphragms using a ‘bus-bar’ arrangement consisting of a two-wire feed with 30 branched spurs, as illustrated in Figure 5(a). The small form factor of the bus-bar would allow it to be retained on the actuator strip and thus promote integration in the wind tunnel model. However, a key issue is the exposure of a high (and potentially dangerous) electrical current to operate the diaphragms. The main bus-bar conductors leaving the diaphragm drive signal amplifier carry the current for all the diaphragms, which are wired in parallel. Coupled with the relatively high-drive voltage required for the diaphragms raises the potential hazard of this exposure. To quantify, it is necessary to provide a peak-to-peak drive voltage (Vpp) of nominally 200 Vpp to achieve the required jet velocity. The diaphragms each have a maximum resonant impedance of 300 ohms and hence have a current draw of 0.67 A; a total of 20 A for the bus-bar. Figure 5.
Connectivity schematic of SJA diaphragm and in-actuator microphone wiring. PCB: printed circuit board; SJA: synthetic jet actuator.

Consequently, large conductor cross-sectional areas and double insulation may be required for risk mitigation. This would also be the case for spliced connections. For the bus-bar arrangement proposed in Figure 5(a), the spliced cables would consist of three wires soldered together and covered in two layers of insulation. Creating a safe and robust connection in this manner starts to become bulky and can make rework particularly difficult if faults arise.

The final connectivity solution adopted is illustrated in Figure 5(b). The diaphragm drive system collectively consists of an electronic amplifier and voltage distribution junction box. The function of the junction box is to provide a capability for connecting the diaphragms to a common drive voltage source. The junction box comprises a 200 × 200 × 70 mm3 polycarbonate enclosure with radio frequency interference (RFI) screening which houses a number of DIN rail-mounted terminals which are configured to ‘fan-out’ an input voltage to 30 outputs. The output voltages are made available on a 100-way micro-miniature D-type plug, as shown in Figure 5(b), which allows total disconnection of the SJA array. An earth or screen terminal is provided which contacts the RFI screen of the box and also provides the option of screening the output voltages. The diaphragm drive system is sized according to the electrical current loading of the SJA array, with the junction box designed to accept an input of at least 200 Vpp at 20 A and provide 30 outputs of 200 Vpp at 0.67 A.

The diaphragms are connected to the junction box via a loom of 30 screened twisted wire pairs mated to a plug/socket cable. The cables are a two-way, COTS component (Omnetics A24000-02 male connector and A25000-002 female connector) and therefore allow local disconnection of a diaphragm. The maximum cable current capacity is 3 A, which satisfies operational requirements of the SJA diaphragm. Other desirable features of this cable include small form factor for its current and voltage ratings; PTFE insulation to MIL-M-24519; pre-wired and back-potted to minimise wire fatigue and built to comply with shock and vibration requirements of MIL-DTL-83513.

The final connectivity design benefits from reduced exposure of high-electrical currents by the use of a junction box and multiple, low current-carrying wires to the diaphragms as opposed to a single bus-bar arrangement. The implementation of diaphragms in a ‘plug and play’ manner also simplifies fault isolation and facilitates diaphragm replacement without affecting the whole array. However, Figure 5 shows that the wiring overhead is much reduced for the bus-bar arrangement, albeit at a higher electrical risk. Furthermore, the bus-bar arrangement would allow complete wiring installation into the wind tunnel model, which is only partially the case for the final design due to the presence of the junction box.

In this design, 30 screen twisted wire pairs were used to couple the microphones to the printed circuit board (PCB) of the monitoring system, as shown in Figure 5(b). The PCB electronics consist of components for amplifying and monitoring the microphone signals. It was decided to house the electronics according to these two functions on two different PCBs, to avoid using long cables on the microphones. The microphone amplifier PCB would be housed in the wind tunnel model next to the SJA array, with the monitoring PCB housed outside of the model for ease of display. Both sets of PCBs are interfaced together by shielded round-to-flat cables.

sec.title: Health monitoring
sec.p: Health monitoring for the N56 and AVERT SJA arrays has previously consisted of measuring peak jet velocity using a hot wire anemometer prior to wind tunnel testing. However, this can only be done infrequently and changes in actuator performance or even actuator failure during wind tunnel testing are not noted. The design aim was for a simple circuit that would monitor the individual acoustic pressure outputs from each SJA chamber using COTS miniature electret microphones. Reduction in the fluctuating pressure levels inside the chamber (due to a failing diaphragm for example) would result in a jet exit velocity loss.

An orifice from the microphone housing (Figure 3(c)) direct to the respective SJA chamber ensures that the level of acoustic energy is high relative to the background acoustic noise from adjacent actuators. As previously noted, the actuator monitoring system was built on two PCBs – a microphone amplifier PCB and a microphone monitoring PCB. A schematic of the signal processing steps between these two circuits is shown in Figure 6. Complete circuit diagrams and a list of components are provided in Appendix 2. Figure 6.
Signal processing route for the actuator health monitoring system. PCB: printed circuit board; LED: light emitting diode.

The microphone generates an output voltage which is proportional to the acoustic pressure level inside the SJA chamber. This signal is subsequently amplified and rectified using a half-wave rectifier with unity gain on the amplifier PCB. The microphone signal then passes through a single-pole, low-pass filter on the monitoring PCB, to reduce any ambient, low-amplitude background noise from adjacent actuators. This filtered signal forms one input to a voltage comparator. The other comparator input comes from a multi-turn preset (trimming potentiometer or variable resistor) that is used to set a threshold voltage. The output of the comparator drives a two-colour light emitting diode (LED) to indicate when the actuator is working; green indicates a microphone signal greater than the threshold point while red indicates a signal less than the threshold. The threshold for each SJA can be set as a percentage of the nominal SJA drive voltage by manually tuning the variable resistor. Both circuits use the standard technique of biasing the positive input of the amplifier so that a single positive power supply can be used.

sec.title: Actuator performance validation
sec.p: The array was bench-tested to validate output jet velocity performance. Sinusoidal excitation was supplied to each actuator using a Thurlby Thandar TG1010A signal generator. The signal was amplified up to a peak-to-peak voltage of 300 Vpp using a Trek PZD350 piezo power amplifier. Jet velocities were measured under quiescent conditions with a hot-wire anemometer system composed of a Dantec 55P11 hot-wire probe and a DISA 55M01 unit. Full details of the testing and calibration procedure are similar to those described in Crowther and Gomes.31

Figure 7 shows the velocity response as a function of excitation frequency for a SJA from the array (denoted as ‘baseline clamping’). The peak jet velocity Upeak obtained for a diaphragm drive voltage of 100 Vpp is 42 m/s at a frequency of 1.8 kHz, which was found to be consistent across the array. A smaller peak velocity of Upeak = 37 m/s is observed at a frequency of 2.2 kHz. Increasing the voltage to 300 Vpp at 1.8 kHz increases Upeak to 85 m/s, which is comparable to the baseline adjacent SJA for a reduced array height. However, Upeak values for the baseline adjacent SJA and the baseline opposite SJA were obtained at 2.6 kHz. Figure 7.
SJA peak jet velocity response as a function of excitation frequency. Vpp = 100 V.

It has been shown37 that the frequency response of a SJA is consistent with that of a damped fourth-order system governed by two key resonance frequencies – the chamber Helmholtz resonance fH and the diaphragm mechanical resonance fD. For a SJA with a round orifice and cylindrical chamber, fH is given by (1)fH=a2πg(dDg)21Hh where a is the speed of sound. For the present SJA design, equation (1) gives fH = 1.9 kHz, which is close to the excitation frequency (1.8 kHz) at which the larger Upeak is obtained in the velocity response in Figure 7.

For a circular plate akin to a SJA diaphragm, fD is given by38 (2)fD=k22πg(1rD2EIρtD(1-ν2)g) where rD and tD are the diaphragm radius and thickness, respectively; E, ρ and ν represent the diaphragm material properties (Young’s modulus, density and Poisson’s ratio, respectively); I is the second moment of area of inertia and k a dimensionless frequency parameter, which is primarily a function of the diaphragm boundary conditions: k2 = 10.22 for a clamped plate and k2 = 4.98 for a simply supported plate.38 For a SJA diaphragm subject to these boundary conditions, fD varies from 4.3 to 2.1 kHz, respectively. The value of fD for the simply supported plate is close to the excitation frequency (2.2 kHz) at which the smaller Upeak is obtained in the velocity response in Figure 7. It is worth recalling the function of the O-ring in the present design, which is to confer an increase in reliability by relaxing the clamping condition and hence bending stress during operation. It was shown39 that the value of fD obtained for this relaxed clamping condition from equation (2) (with an additional damping term(1-2ξ), where ξ is an empirically obtained damping coefficient: ξ = 0.06) was 2.8 kHz, which is close to the resonant frequency (2.6 kHz) obtained for the baseline opposite SJA.

To summarise:
The baseline opposite SJA (which is a velocity-optimised configuration) has Upeak at 2.6 kHz, which is close to the diaphragm resonant frequency (2.8 kHz) when operated with an O-ring.
It is hypothesised that the velocity response of the geometrically similar SJA design in the present array is dominated by the chamber Helmholtz resonance at 1.8 kHz, while the smaller peak observed at 2.2 kHz corresponds to the diaphragm mechanical resonance.
The reduced fD (relative to the baseline opposite SJA) and reduced Upeak (relative to that at fH) of the present SJA suggest an issue with the stiffness of the diaphragm clamping, namely the compressive loading imparted on the O-ring and the diaphragm by the cover is not sufficiently high.

The SJA arrangement for the present design (Figure 3(d)) is such that the diaphragm is clamped by the cover, which in turn is clamped to the top plate via three fasteners on one side of its perimeter and via compression by the adjacent overlapping SJA on the other side of its perimeter. To verify the effect of the clamping arrangement, a single SJA of the array design was replicated with a modified cover to allow four fasteners to be attached, equally spaced around its perimeter. The velocity response of the SJA with modified clamping at 100 Vpp is plotted in Figure 7 for comparison with the baseline clamping arrangement. It can be seen that a peak jet velocity emerges at Upeak = 46 m/s and f = 2.7 kHz. The velocity response is similar in shape to that of the baseline opposite SJA in Crowther and Gomes.31 Furthermore, Figure 8 shows the effect of increasing Vpp on Upeak for the two alternative clamping arrangements. The percentage increases in Upeak from the modified arrangement compared to the baseline at 100, 150, 200 and 300 Vpp are 10%, 21%, 29% and 19 %, respectively. The maximum Upeak returned from the SJA with modified clamping is 102 m/s at 300 Vpp. For both cases, the rate of increase in Upeak obtained from the SJA increases with Vpp up to 200 V, after which the rate of increase reduces. Thus, the 200 V voltage corresponds to the maximum point of the rate of increase of Upeak. This is due to the fact that at the higher voltages the piezoceramic material starts to saturate, bearing in mind that the PZT diaphragms used are specified for a nominal operating voltage of around 30 V. Figure 8.
SJA peak jet velocity response as a function of excitation peak-to-peak voltage at resonant frequencies.

Results from the performance validation tests have shown that the SJA array would benefit from a diaphragm clamping arrangement which confers increased preload on the diaphragm. To retain the present SJA cover design shown in Figure 3(d) and SLA fabrication process, the SJA cover could be manufactured from an alternative polymer such as Bluestone®. The density of Bluestone® is greater than the presently used Xtreme by a factor of 1.5 and has a mechanical stiffness greater by a factor of 4, which would therefore increase the effective mass acting on the O-ring and diaphragm (albeit at a cost of increasing the overall mass of the SJA array). Alternatively, or in addition to the suggested modification, stiffener rails could be fitted across the length of the array onto which each SJA cover would be fastened. This would have the added advantage of increasing the overall stiffness of the SJA array and thus making it more robust, albeit at a cost of a small increase in the array height.

sec.title: Development of an actuator array design methodology
sec.p: Lessons learned from this study were applied towards developing a methodology for designing a SJA array for flow separation control applications. The aim of the present methodology is to allow the flow control practitioner to produce a usable SJA array design with a set of requirements different from that of this study, but within the constraints of using the same actuator technology in a similar application. The lead author has previously had involvement in establishing a methodology for designing SJAs for flow separation control.40 This design method was focused on selecting the actuator geometry and operating conditions to maximise SJA impact on the local boundary layer, but without imposing the constraints associated with an array, such as orifice spacing and installation height. The present methodology brings together design experience gained in PZT diaphragm characterisation for SJAs39 and optimisation of SJA operating conditions for separation control40 with volume-constrained SJA array design from this study.

A flow chart summarising the design process is shown in Figure 9 and described here in detail. The starting point is a user-defined target height for the array tA (which should also allow space for wiring installation), an actuator array length sA and free stream velocity U∞, all of which are set by the prescribed test model and test conditions. Knowledge of the model dimensions and U∞ allows the local boundary layer thickness δ at the target location to be defined, either by direct measurement or use of panel method tools such as JavaFoil.41 The orifice diameter d is sized within the limits, 5–20%, of δ for separation control effectiveness, with a minimum d set to 0.5 mm based on machining limitations and viscous damping effects. Thereafter, two different separation control strategies can be pursued: maximising SJA velocity for momentum injection or maximising SJA vorticity for momentum redistribution (via injection of coherent vortices). Each strategy generates a different SJA design, namely in the selection of the orifice height h. For the velocity-optimised SJA, h = 2.1d31 and for the vorticity-optimised SJA, h = 0.5d to maximise the strength of vortex rollup.40 The latter SJA design also includes optional settings for orifice pitch (α = 45°) and skew (β = 90°) to maximise vorticity bias for improved separation control effectiveness,42 which is applicable for regions where the sign of the boundary layer vorticity is also biased, e.g. on a swept wing model. Figure 9.
Flow chart showing the process for designing a piezoelectric-based SJA array for flow separation control applications. SJA: synthetic jet actuator; PZT: polycrystalline lead zirconate titanate.

Output of the chamber diameter D permits selection of a suitably sized piezoelectric disc for the SJA diaphragm, where diaphragm radius rD∼D/2. Typical dimensions of COTS PZT diaphragms (including diaphragm thickness tD) are provided in the look-up table in Figure 9. Alternatively, a bespoke single crystal piezoceramic solution, e.g. lead magnesium niobate (PMN), can be pursued with the added advantage of offering inherently higher efficiencies and mechanical strains compared to polycrystalline piezoceramics. The look-up table in Figure 9 includes a typical range of rD and tD values for a bespoke single-crystal diaphragm.

The selected diaphragm geometry can be used to compute the diaphragm resonant frequency fD, which defines the desired operating frequency for maximum actuator authority and energy efficiency in a frequency-coupled (fD and fH) SJA velocity response. Additional inputs for calculating fD include the diaphragm material properties E, ρ and ν (which are similar for both PZT and PMN) and the diaphragm boundary conditions k and ξ. The dimensionless frequency parameter k and diahragm damping coefficient ξ were empirically obtained39 for a range of rD (7.5, 10, 13.5 and 17.5 mm). The value of k obtained for the relaxed clamping condition with use of variable-diameter, constant cross-section (1.78 mm) nitrile O-rings was k∼7.08. As such, the look-up table in Figure 9 includes COTS nitrile O-rings for selection with the corresponding diaphragm and with a constant cross-section of 1.78 mm to ensure that k = 7.08 is valid for all cases. The value of ξ was found to vary from 0.066 to 0.046 for the predefined range of rD, reducing with rD and increasing with tD. A value of ξ = 0.06 is assumed for the present methodology. The equation for fD in Figure 9 shows that ξ will have a negligible impact on the value of fD itself.

Subsequent criteria for maximising the control effectiveness of each SJA design are based on conformity to a range of dimensionless operating parameters. For the velocity-optimised SJA, the jet-to-free stream velocity ratio VR should be of the order of unity for separation control effectiveness. Also, the stroke length L should be greater than unity to ensure jet formation; failure to meet this criterion requires an iteration in the design loop to adjust the selected value of Δ within the predefined limits. For the vorticity-optimised SJA, there are additional requirements that include Stokes number S greater than 10 to ensure vortex rollup and Strouhal number St (based on δ and U∞) greater than 0.1 to ensure spacing between successive vortices of the order of δ to maximise their impact on the boundary layer.40 Similarly, an iteration in Δ is needed if the minimum requirements for either S or St are not met. There is evidence43,44 to suggest that hairpin vortices are the desired structures for delaying flow separation, requiring VR to be set in the range 0.3–1. The value of VR can be adjusted within the predefined range to obtain a value of L between 1 and 5 required to generate hairpin vortices.

Upon completion of these preliminary steps, it is necessary to validate the SJA peak jet velocity Upeak acheivable for each design via a combination of numerical simulation and hot-wire bench test of a prototype. For a minor shortfall in the measured Upeak relative to that required from the design method, the diaphragm peak-to-peak drive voltage Vpp can be increased (typically, maximum Vpp = 300 V for COTS PZT FT-27 T-3.9A1 or a 0.2-mm thick single-crystal). Otherwise, for a major shortfall in Upeak, an iteration of the design method is required with an adjustment in VR or Δ to reduce the required Upeak. Alternatively, the SJA chamber diameter D can be directly increased. However, this should be a last option. Increasing D can increase Upeak by way of a larger chamber-to-orifice area ratio and through inherent use of a larger diameter piezoceramic diaphragm, with the ability to absorb more electrical power. However, large increases in D may compromise the target height for the array.

Once Upeak has been validated, the SJA geometric parameters can be used to design the array. The ratio of actuator spanwise spacing to orifice diameter λ is set within the limits of 5 ≤ λ ≤ 20 for separation control effectiveness. For the predefined value of λ, the number of actuators n required in the array can then be determined from sA, δ and Δ; the latter finalised from the Upeak validation. The subsequent activity of inclining and overlapping SJAs as part of an array should be carried out within a 3D CAD environment, to ensure overall feasibility of the design and conformity to geometric and actuator spacing requirements. An additional constraint in the SJA inclination process is to restrict the offset between the orifice and diaphragm centre <0.1D to ensure that Upeak remains comparable to the non-inclined SJA. Finally, the output value of tA can be compared with the initial target; a value that exceeds the target requires an iteration in the design loop to adjust the selected value of λ within the predefined limits. An output value of tA within the target concludes the design process.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study has documented the design and development of SJA hardware in response to delivering an array of 30 SJAs to augment high-lift system effectiveness in a wind tunnel model. The study has involved (a) the development of an array to meet reduced volume installation constraints without a loss in peak jet exit velocity relative to a baseline array,5 (b) provision of proper SJA systems wiring for model installation and (c) implementation of a basic actuator health monitoring system. The baseline array consists of ‘adjacent’ SJAs in which the jet orifice for each actuator is located on the chamber wall perpendicular to the oscillating boundary. The baseline array confers suitable actuator spacing (actuator spanwise spacing-to-orifice diameter ratio λ∼10) for separation control effectiveness, but exceeds volume installation constraints for the present model envelope by a factor of two.

Specific conclusions from the SJA array design work are as follows.
Volume-constrained implementation of an array of velocity-optimised ‘opposite’ SJAs31 (orifice plate parallel to the oscillating boundary) with the constraints of using the same commercially sourced piezoceramic diaphragms (project time requirement) and actuator spacing λ∼10 (separation control-optimised requirement) as the baseline array, required SJAs to be inclined ∼20° relative to the wetted surface to allow actuator overlapping. As a result, the placement height of the array was reduced by a factor of 0.5 compared to the baseline model.
Manufacture of the inclined SJA array was realised through the SLA rapid prototyping technique, which enabled the ability to include more complex geometry (i.e. arced wall chamber and internal orifice filleting) while reducing part count per SJA by 33% and manufacturing lead-time by 75% compared to conventional metal/electrical discharge machining used for the baseline array.
The peak jet velocity obtained from the inclined SJA array was 100 m/s at an input voltage and excitation frequency 300 Vpp and 2.7 kHz, respectively. This favourably compares to the baseline array (90 m/s, at 250 Vpp and 2.6 kHz) while reducing usable depth requirements by 50%.
The inclined SJA array would benefit from increased compressive loading of individual SJA covers on the diaphragms to maximise velocity output, which may be achieved via use of higher density SLA material for the same SJA cover design or additional stiffener rails fitted across the length of the array to each cover at a cost of a small increase in the array height.

Specific conclusions from the SJA systems work are as follows.
The electrical wiring system adopted to interface SJAs with the diaphragm drive amplifier consisted of a voltage distribution junction box with a multi-wire connector, allowing connection of individual SJAs in a ‘plug and play' manner. Both the wiring and junction box incorporated insulation and screening to shield against exposure to the high current and was thus preferred to a more exposed ‘bus-bar' wiring arrangement, albeit at an increase in wiring overhead and volume installation requirement.
The use of distributed pressure sensors in the array in the form of small microphones housed in each SJA provides simple and effective health monitoring. Microphones were used to show reductions in actuator performance relative to a preset voltage in the monitoring circuit via a two-colour LED (green/red ‘go/no-go’ status). At full scale, implementation of health monitoring is likely to be critical for the certification of active flow control actuators as part of a wider aircraft configuration warning system.

The final outcome of this study has been to apply the design lessons learned to develop a methodology for designing a SJA array. The methodology allows the flow control practitioner to produce a usable SJA array design (based on the ‘opposite’ SJA configuration) with a different set of model requirements and test conditions, but with the constraints of using piezoelectric-based actuator technology for flow separation control applications.
